comments.commentBody: But he did not take his gift for granted. He chose to revive the secret because his wife threatened to leave him if he did not reveal why he was laughing. If he had taken his gift for granted he would have revealed the secret of the tooth the first time his wife asked what was so funny.
This is a test for 3rd graders, though.
Best, and most concise post on this whole thread
The easy questions are easy and the "tricky" questions are stupid. The authors of this test are unfit to participate in the educational process in any way.

I, too, got 100 percent.  Since we're in the same club, I'll offer some advice.  Don't be proud about performing well on a test for third graders.  100 percent should be the minimum standard for adults.
What's bad about the last question?  Understanding the passage revealed one answer to be clearly better than the other three.

Editing the above to get under the character limit changed the meaning of a sentence above somewhat.  A key sentence should read "Learning to keep a promise or a secret may bring a reward that is "more trouble" than it is worth?".  Please Mr. Pirotta, side with the kids. That is not what your story says. It is simply what the testers wanted the kids to answer.
Really?  The trouble is that to keep the reward, he sacrifices his wife.
... but are you a third grader?
You're also not a third grader...
The protagonist clearly thought it's more trouble than it's worth.  To keep the charmed tooth, he would have lost his wife.  He chose to sacrifice the power of the tooth to keep his wife.

And I disagree. Remember the standards call for using text evidence. And in the text he learned that mice were going to try to eat his leftover bread and the milkman was going to try to sell him watered down milk. This is txt evidence for the reward being a very good thing indeed. Yes, there was some tension with his wife-but that was more implicit than explicit.  The text mentions his wife asking about his laughing, but no tension was referred to (and this test is being taken by a third grader, not an experienced married person who knows the consequence of these kinds of actions-) So, the for a third grader, where is the evidence in the text for "rewards can be more trouble than they are worth". For Niel only lost his reward when he disobeyed the condition of having the reward. Where in the text does it show this? (remember: you are a third grader, not an adult taking this test)
Give the test to the Supreme Court and see how many of them disagree with each other.

I don't see why Spanglish should be barred if Yinglish is accepted and used with some frequency.  Purists about Yiddish and French words have had to come to terms with words like 'kibitz' and APROPOS having changed there meanings and how they're used.  I clung a long time to APROPOS myself, today just had a frisson of regret.
Yeesh. 'Their' meanings. And that there wasn't even an Autocorrect.

"Uno" momento isn't Spanglish. It's not even colloquial. To this Spanish speaker's ears, it's just plain WRONG. I don't see how Will could have allowed this.

As for UELE, it's almost crosswordese to me, so I was surprised to read here that it has been used only 135 times. But then, I started doing the NYT Puzzle a long, long time ago, so I've probably entered it 135 times.
UN momento. Solo UN momento. If such a mistake is intentional, there should be quotation marks for whatever movie it refers to, or a change of the clue altogether. It looks awful and amateurish.
I see your point, but it would be really sad to turn the many-sided debates into a competition for "I Have It Worse Than You."

The Black Lives Movement is beginning to create a backlash. The news media responded to the first round of Ferguson protests by tracking police homicides and compiling databases, but these databases revealed that the overwhelming majority of police homicide victims are white. Black Lives Matter advocates responded to this unexpected revelation by resorting to unconvincing statistical gimmickry. They declared blacks make up a disproportionate number of police homicide victims compared to their percent of the total population, but the racial disparity in police homicide victims vanishes when the percentage of black victims is compared to the racial disparity in the number of arrests. The Black Lives Movement blamed the Charleston church massacre on Jeff Davis and Confederate battle flags, but in his Facebook manifesto, Dylann Roof blamed black-on-white violence and his perception that news media’s unfairly focuses on white-on-black murders while ignoring white-on-black murders. In light of the Charleston church murders and recent Ferguson violence, the news media should ask itself if its almost exclusive focus on black victims is beginning to generate rather than reduce interracial violence.

I would like to see stories in the New York Times about communities that have good relationships between the police and minority communities.  This focus on victimhood and negativity is getting us no where.  Where are some models that can be followed?
Yup - now vandalism and destruction of property belonging to others is now "good clean fun."
I have no clue what you are trying to say and I did answer correctly all the third grade questions.

Yes, indeed. What Douthat fails to recognise would fill volumes. Here, again, he ignores that there is no such such thing as 'garden-variety American conservatism' -- hasn't been for most of his life. Reagan killed it. Saint Ron was genial, with a B-movie-actor schtick making everyone comfortable with deeply ugly ideas dressed as homespun homilies and poor arithmetic disguised as common sense. His racism was painted with cartoonish lies ('welfare queens') and passive aggressive gestures (a states' rights campaign kick-off speech in a Mississippi county where the Klan murdered civil rights workers).

From the all-hallowed Reagan era forward there has been no hope for conservatism. Fiscal prudence was replaced permanently by GOP profligacy and exploding deficits (inevitably brought down by Democratic administrations). Seventy per cent of the national debt (which makes the Republican base keen and wail) came from Reagan and the various Bush family incompetents to follow in his path.

The GOP has festered (like the Democratic party did in the thrall of strains of leftism a generation ago) and created a toxicity that prevents any reasonableness, any compromise, any governance.

Trump is no Republican. He is a narcissist, worshipping only himself. But the fetid vacuousness of the GOP has given him the perfect stage.

Sorry, Ross, but both reform conservatism and 'garden-variety American conservatism' are lies. Conservatism today is a cruel, backward looking false faith.

comments.userDisplayName: I'm not sure I heard right?
comments.commentBody: I can't make out what issue you're taking with the article? Help me out?

""one that bears little resemblance to garden-variety American conservatism.""

Ross is, as with much, too clueless to know how pathetic this is. Of course Ross and his cronies are accountable for nothing, they are republican misdescribed conservatives, ni more the real thing that a lightening bug is lightening. Sophistry is all they need.

Of course, Ross and his fellow american right wing Catholic buddies, are busy making distictions without a difference, while remaining party loyalists who use their sophistry to keep the party in power. It is what they do. They are every but as conservative as eggplants--pick your variety, none are conservative.

Oh what I will not give for a Judgment Day. Ross and Reihan are midwives (wombless of course, it is what gives them their special abortion expertise, like the Fathers by not being the one whose body is involved) to Donald's spawning. Along with all the other oligarch drones, hacks and rentiers.

There are two different issues here - there's the issue of what the distal causes are of the situation of African Americans today, and then there's the question of what can be done about it.  Yes, slavery and our history of Jim Crow have had terrible effects.  But we can't go back and make that history not happen.   So the question now is what to do and there is some reason to believe that the attempts we have made thus far have made the problems worse, not better. (There is more social dysfunction in the African American community today than there was 60 years ago - why is that?)    So maybe it's time to try something else.  And so why not try strategies that have worked for other poor communities?
There were no deaths in the recent measles outbreak, but what about other effects, like vision problems? It isn't always about deaths. My mother lost the sight of one eye due to measles.

This is a joke. These guys have not produced a single breakthrough that makes money or is ahead in innovation since the original search and ad engines. These are boys with toy who don't want to run a serious business. This is a science fair on shareholder's money. See how sensitive and caring they are about shareholders, maybe they will end the special share-holder hostile super majority stock.
Google 411 served its purpose, which was to train their speech recognition system.
Don't forget "disrupt".  That seems to be the word of the day.

Eric,

They are restructuring because holding companies and their subsidiaries are considered separate legal entities, so that the assets and liabilities of the parent company and the individual subsidiaries are protected against claims against one of the subsidiaries.

For example, massive fines for Google in Europe for selling Google data users' information, which is against European law, will only affect the Google Europe subsidiary, and not Alphabet. Holding company laws make it quite easy to sell non-performing or problematic subsidiaries, which Google Europe may become.

The tax advantage is that losses from one subsidiary can be used to offset profits from another subsidiary and reduce the overall taxable corporate income on the consolidated tax return. It turns a poorly performing subsidiary into an asset, for the sake of paying lower taxes.

Further, subsidiaries can be established in countries with tax laws more favorable to Alphabet subsidiaries, and only the subsidiary can be charged with tax evasion, not the Alphabet parent company.

I don't believe that Google/Alphabet is thinking about "what kind of company they want to become". They exist, period.

Alphabet wants to pay lower taxes and continue to sell user data, in essence, maximize profits, without suffering any negative consequences. They are a corporate giant, Eric, and not so naive or innocent as you may think.

YouTube ads make money, Android gets some cents per phone it is on, the Play Store makes money (royalties on apps and in app purchases, music purchases), Nexus made some, Nest, and potential profits could be from Ara, the self driving car, and glass if they take off. You are absolutely right that search ads are the biggest, but I think youtube ads and the play store are pretty big contributors as well now.

I wonder how many of Google's ventures make money. I've read everything is held afloat by Search advertising, which is the only Google business that is profitable - it makes lots of money, enough to finance all their other projects, big and small, useful and pie-in-in-the-sky.

What kind of company does Google - er, Alphabet - want to become? I doubt they know, beyond the vague idea of "innovate."

I guess this new structure allows Google to have 2 businesses, 2 approaches: Google, i.e., Search, which makes oodles of dough and is very useful, and Everything Else They Can Think Of to spend their money on to, of course, "innovate."

I know of no Executive Order to compel one to use Google. There are other search engines. If one doesn't like Google and still uses it, perhaps the reason is that s/he's too busy to look for an alternative or lacks a secretary or other aid to do so.

As to understanding Alphabet's corporate and tax structure, I wouldn't trust the IRS to do it. Might not the GAO look into what needs to be clarified? G-d forbid that there should be Congressional hearings. Oh, I almost forgot. The Republicans hold the majority in each house.

Sounds like a ploy to seal off the profitable advertising generator from liability associated with driverless cars running down pedestrians. In other words, they are not having much luck getting states to re-write their traffic liability laws to benefit Google Inc.

Careful. You may be called down because the name Alladin is known from the Arabic "Tales of a thousand nights and one night," is it not?

Perhaps Merlin might do. If not, someone will certainly suggest a non-gender specific name.
